bibl.title: Letter from William H. Taft to Carlos J. Finlay, October 4, 1906

div1.p: Taft writes that Kean has been detailed to assist Finlay in stamping out yellow fever in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from William H. Taft to Carlos J. Finlay, October 4, 1906
div1.opener:
(COPY)
Office of the Governor.
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
UNDER THE PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION
OF THE UNITED STATES.
Havana, October 4, 1906.
My dear Doctor Finlay:
div1.p:
I do not need to introduce to you Major Kean, of the Medi-
cal Corps, U.S. Army, because you have had a long acquaintance with
him and I understand from you that that acquaintance has brought
about mutual respect and friendship.

I am, as you know, very anxious to assist you in the one-
rous and critical work of stamping out yellow fever, which seems
to have obtained some foothold in the city and island. I have de-
tailed Major Kean to assist you in this matter with his advice as
a volunteer side, and I hope you will consult him fully and that
you will receive and follow his suggestions, especially with res-
pect to the reorganization of your department and the necessary
additions to the force. Major Kean's standing in his profession
and his great executive ability I know you are aware of, and that
you will be very glad to avail yourself of both.

I repeat, as I said to you last night, there must be no
lack of energy in this work, which is of the highest importance
both to the sanitary and business interests of the island.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (F) Wm. H. Taft. Dr. Carlos Finley,
Chief of Sanitation.
(ES COPIA FIEL DEL ORIGINAL).
